editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The shoemakers holiday. Or the gentle craft.
With the humorous life of Simon Eyre, shoemaker, and lord mayor of London.
As it was acted before the Queen's most excellent majesty on new years day at night last, by the right honourable the Earl of Nottingham, lord high admiral of England, his servants.
Printed by Valentine Sims dwelling at the foot of Adling hill, near Bainard's castle, at the sign of the white swan, and are there to be sold. 1600.

opener.salute: To all good fellows, professors of the gentle craft; of what degree soever.

div.p: Kind gentlemen, and honest boon companions, I present you here with a merry conceited comedy, called the shoemaker's holiday, acted by my lord admiral's players this present Christmas, before the Queen's most excellent majesty. For the mirth and pleasant matter, by her highness graciously accepted; being indeed no way offensive. The argument of the play I will set down in this epistle: sir Hugh Lacy Earl of Lincoln, had a young gentleman of his own name, his near kinsman, that loved the lord mayor's daughter of London; to prevent and cross which love, the Earl caused his kinsman to be sent colonel of a company into France: who resigned his place to another gentleman his friend, and came disguised like a Dutch shoemaker, to the house of Simon Eyre in tower street, who served the mayor and his household with shoes. The merriments that passed in Eyre's house, his coming to be mayor of London, Lacy's getting his love, and other accidents; with two merry three-men's songs. Take all in good worth that is well intended, for nothing is purposed but mirth, mirth lengthneth long life which, with all other blessings I heartily wish you.

lg.l: O the month of May, the merry month of May,
So frolic, so gay, and so green, so green, so green:
Oh and then did I, unto my true love say,
Swate Peg, thou shalt be my summer's Queen.
Now the nightingale, the pretty nightingale,
The sweetest singer in all the forest's quire:
Entreats thee sweet Peggy, to hear thy true love's tale,
Lo, yonder she sitteth, her breast against a brier.
But oh I spy the cuckoo, the cuckoo, the cuckoo,
See where she sitteth, come away my joy:
Come away I prithee, I do not like the cuckoo
Should sing where my Peggy and I kiss and toy.
O the month of May, the merry month of May,
So frolic, so gay, and so green, so green, so green:
And then did I, unto my true love say,
Sweet Peg, thou shalt be my summer's Queen.

div.head: The second threeman's song.
div.stage: This is to be sung at the latter end.

lg.l: Cold's the wind, and wet's the rain,
Saint Hugh be our good speed:
Ill is the weather that bringeth no gain,
Nor helps good hearts in need.
Troll the bowl, the jolly nutbrown bowl,
And here kind mate to thee:
Let's sing a dirge for saint Hugh's soul,
And down it merrily.
Down a down, heigh down a down,
Heigh derie derie down a down,
Close with the tenor boy:
Ho well done, to me let come,
King compass gentle joy.
Troll the bowl, the nutbrown bowl,
And here kind etc. as often as there be men to drink.
At last when all have drunk, this verse.
Cold's the wind, and wet's the rain,
Saint Hugh be our good speed:
Ill is the weather that bringeth no gain,
Nor helps good hearts in need.

div.head: The prologue as it was pronounced before the Queen's majesty.
div.l: As wretches in a storm (Expecting day)
With trembling hands and eyes cast up to heaven,
Make prayers the anchor of their conquered hopes,
So we (Dear goddess) wonder of all eyes,
Your meanest vassals (Through mistrust and fear,
To uncke into the bottom of disgrace,
By our imperfect pastimes) prostrate thus
On bent knees, our sails of hope do strike,
Dreading the bitter storms of your dislike.
Since then (Unhappy men) our hap is such,
That to ourselves ourselves no help can bring,
But needs must perish, if your saintlike cares
(Locking the temple where all mercy sits)
Refuse the tribute of our begging tongues.
O grant (Bright mirror of true chastity)
From those life-breathing stars your sunlike eyes,
One gracious smile: for your celestial breath
Must send us life, or sentence us to death.

div.head: A pleasant comedy of the gentle craft.

sp.speaker: Lincoln.
sp.l: My lord mayor, you have sundry times
Feasted myself, and many courtiers more,
Seldom, or never can we be so kind,
To make requital of your courtesy:
But leaving this, I hear my cousin Lacy
Is much affected to your daughter Rose.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.p: True my good lord, and she loves him so well, that I mislike her boldness in the chase.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.p: Why my lord mayor, think you it then a shame, to join a Lacy with an Oteley's name?

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: Too mean is my poor girl for his high birth,
Poor citizens must not with courtiers wed,
Who will in silks, and gay apparel spend
More in one year, than I am worth by far,
Therefore your honour need not doubt my girl.

sp.speaker: Lincoln.
sp.l: Take heed my lord, advise you what you do,
A berier unthrift lives not in the world,
Then is my cousin, for I'll tell you what,
'tis now almost a year since he requested
To travel countries for experience,
I furnished him with coin, bills of exchange,
Letters of credit, men to wait on him,
Solicited my friends in Italy
Well to respect him: but to see the end:
Scant had he journeyed through half Germany,
But all his coin was spent, his men cast off,
His bills embezzled, and my jolly coz,
Ashamed to show his bankrupt presence here,
Became a shoemaker in Wittenberg,
A goodly science for a gentleman
Of such descent: now judge the rest by this.
Suppose your daughter have a thousand pound,
He did consume me more in one half year,
And make him heir to all the wealth you have,
One twelvemonth's rioting will waste it all,
Then seek (My lord) some honest citizen
To wed your daughter to.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: I thank your lordship,
Well fore, I understand your subtlety,
As for your nephew, let your lordship's eye
But watch his actions, and you need not fear,
For I have my daughter far enough,
And yet your cousin Rowland might do well
Now he hath learned an occupation,
And yet I scorn to call him son in law.

sp.speaker: Lincoln.
sp.l: I but I have a better trade for him,
I thank his grace he hath appointed him,
Chief colonel of all those companies
Mustered in London, and the shires about,
To serve his highness in those wars of France:
See where he comes: Lovel what news with you?

sp.speaker: Louell.
sp.l: My lord of Lincoln, 'tis his highness' will,
That presently your cousin ship for France
With all his powers, he would not for a million,
But they should land at deep within four days.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.l: Go certify his grace it shall be done:Exit Lovell.
Now cousin Lacy, in what forwardness
Are all your companies?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: All well prepared,
The men of Hartfordshire lie at mile end,
Suffolk, and Essex, train in Tuttle fields,
The Londoners, and those of Middlesex,
All gallantly prepared in Finsbury,
With frolic spirits, long for their parting hour.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: They have their impressed, coats, and furniture,
And if it please your cousin Lacy come
To the Guild-hall , he shall receive his pay,
And twenty pounds besides my brothers
Will freely give him, to approve our loves
We bear unto my lord your uncle here.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: I thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Lincoln.
sp.p: Thanks my good lord mayor.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: At the guild hal we will expect your coming,Exit.

sp.speaker: Lincoln.
sp.l: To approve your loves to me? no subtlety
Nephew: that twenty pound he doth bestow,
For joy to rid you from his daughter Rose:
But cousins both, now here are none but friends,
I would not have you cast an amorous eye
Upon so mean a project, as the love
Of a gay wanton painted citizen,
I know this churl, even in the height of scorn,
Doth hate the mixture of his blood with thine,
I pray thee do thou so, remember coz,
what honourable fortunes wait on thee,
Increase the King's love which so brightly shines,
And gilds thy hopes, I have no heir but thee:
And yet not thee, if with a wayward spirit,
Thou start from the true bias of my love.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: My lord, I will (For honour (Not desire
Of land or livings) or to be your heir)
So guide my actions in pursuit of France,
As shall add glory to the Lacies name.

sp.speaker: Lincoln.
sp.l: Coz, for those words here's thirty Portuguese
And nephew askew, there's a few for you,
Fair honour in her loftrest eminence
Stays in France for you till you fetch her thence,
Then nephews, clap swift wings on your designs,
Be gone, be gone, make haste to the Guild-hall ,
There presently I'll meet you, do not stay,
Where honour becomes, shame attends delay. Exit.

sp.speaker: Askew.
sp.p: How gladly would your uncle have you gone?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: True coz, but I'll o'erreach his policies,
I have some serious business for thrée days,
Which nothing but my presence can dispatch,
You therefore cousin with the companies
Shall haste to Dover, there I'll meet with you,
Or if I stay passed my prefixed time,
Away for France, we'll meet in Normandy,
The twenty pounds my lord maior gives to me
You shall receive, and these ten Portuguese,
Part of mine uncle's thirty, gentle coz,
Have care to our great charge, I know your wisdom
Hath tried itself in higher consequence.

sp.speaker: Askew.
sp.l: Coz, all myself am yours, yet have this care,
To lodge in London with all secrecy,
Our uncle Lincoln hath (Besides his own)
many a jealous eye, that in your face
Stares only to watch means for your disgrace.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Stay cousin, who be these?

div.stage: Enter Symon Eyre, his wife, Hodge, Firk, Jane, and Rafe with a piece.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Leave whining, leave whining, away with this whimpering, this puling, these blubbering tears, and these wet eyes, I'll get thy husband discharged, I warrant thee sweet Jane: go to.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Master, here be the captains.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace Hodge, husht ye knave, husht.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Here be the cavaliers, and the coronels, master.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace Firk, peace my fine Firk, stand by with your pishery-pashery , away, I am a man of the best presence, I'll speak to them and they were Popes, gentlemen, captains, colonels, commanders: brave men, brave leaders, may it please you to give me audience, I am Simon Eyre, the mad shoe-master of Towerstreet, this wench with the mealy mouth that will never tire, is my wife I can tell you, here's Hodge my man, and my foreman, here's Firk my fine firking journeyman, and this is blubbered Jane, all we come to be suitors for this honest Rafe keep him at home, and as I am a true shoemaker, and a gentleman of the gentle craft, buy spurs yourself, and I'll find ye boots these seven years.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Seven years husband?

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace midriff, peace, I know what I do, peace.

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: Truly master cormorant, you shall do God good service to let Rafe and his wife stay together, she's a young new married woman, if you take her husband away from her a night, you undo her, she may beg in the day time, for he's as good a workman at a prick and an awl, as any is in our trade.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: O let him stay, else I shall be undone.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: I truly, she shall be laid at one side like a pair of old shoes else, and be occupied for no use.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Truly my friends, it lies not in my power,
The Londoners are pressed, paid, and set forth
By the lord maior, I cannot change a man.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Why then you were as good be a corporal, as a colonel, if you cannot discharge one good fellow, and I tell you true, I think you do more than you can answer, to presie a man within a year and a day of his marriage.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Well said melancholy Hodge, gramercy my fine foreman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Truly gentlemen, it were ill done, for such as you, to stand so stiffly against a poor young wife: considering her case, she is new married, but let that pass: I pray deal not roughly with her, her husband is a young man and but newly entered, but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Away with your pishery-pashery , your polls and your edipolls, peace Midaffe, silence Cisly Bumtrinket, let your head speak.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Yea and the horns too, master.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Too soon, my fine firk, too soon: peace scoundrels, see you this man? Captains, you will not release him, well let him go, he's a proper shot, let him vanish, peace Jane, dry up thy tears, they'll make his powder darkish, take him brave men, Hector of Troy was an hackney to him, Hercules and termagant scoundrels, prince Arthur's round table, by the lord of Ludgate, ne'er fed such a tall, such a dapper swordman: by the life of Pharo, a brave resolute swordman, peace Jane, I say no more, mad knaves.

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: See, see Hodge, how my master raves in commendation of Rafe.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Raph, thou'rt a gull by this hand, and thou goest.

sp.speaker: Askew.
sp.l: I am glad (Good master air) it is my hap
To meet so resolute a soldier.
Trust me, for your report, and love to him,
a common flight regard shall not respect him.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Is thy name Raph?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Give me thy hand,
Thou shalt not want, as I am a gentleman:
Woman, be patient, God (No doubt) will send
Thy husband safe again, but he must go,
His country's quarrel says, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Thou'rt a gull by my stirrup, if thou dost not go, I will not have thee strike thy gimlet into these weak vessels, prick thine enemies Rafe. Enter Dodger.

sp.speaker: Dodger
sp.l: My lord, your uncle on the tower hill,
Stays with the lord mayor, and the aldermen,
And doth request you with all speed you may
To hasten thither.Exit Dodger.

sp.speaker: Askew
sp.p: Cousin, let's go.

sp.speaker: Lacy,
sp.l: Dodger run you before, tell them we come,
This Dodger is mine uncle's parasite,
The arrantst varlet that e'er breathed on earth,
He sets more discord in a noble house,
By one days broaching of his pickthank falls,
Then can be salved again in twenty years,
And he (I fear) shall go with us to France,
To pry into our actions.

sp.speaker: Askew.
sp.l: Therefore coz,
It shall behoove you to be circumspect,

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Fear not good cousin: Raph, hie to your colours.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: I must, because there's no remedy,
But gentle master and my loving dame,
As you have always been a friend to me,
So in mine absence think upon my wife.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Alas my Raph.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: She cannot speak for weeping.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace you cracked groats, you mustard tokens, disquiet not the brave soldier, go thy ways Raph.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I ay, you bid him go, what shall I do when he is gone?

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: Why be doing with me, or my fellow Hodge, be not idle.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Let me see thy hand Jane, this fine hand, this white hand, these pretty fingers must spin, must card, must work, work you bombast cotton-candle-quean, work for your living with a pox to you: hold thee Raph, here's five sixpences for thee, fight for the honour of the gentle craft, for the gentlemen shoemakers, the courageous cordwainers, the flower of s. Martin's, the mad knaves of bedlam, Fleetstreet, Towerstreet, and white chapel, crack me the crowns of the French knaves, a poor on them, crack them, fight, by the lord of Ludgate, fight my fine boy.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Here Rafe, here's thrée two pences, two carry into France, the third shall wash our souls at parting (For sorrow is dry) for my sake, Firk the Basa mon cues.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Raph, I am heavy at parting, but here's a shilling for thee, God send thee to cram thy slops with French crowns, and thy enemy's bellies with bullets.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: I thank you master, and I thank you all:
Now gentle wife, my loving lovely Jane,
Rich men at parting, give their wives rich gifts,
Jewels and rings, to grace their lily hands,
Thou knowest our trade makes rings for women's heels:
Here take this pair of shoes cut out by Hodge,
Stitched by my fellow Firk, seamed by myself,
Made up and pinked, with letters for thy name,
Wear them my dear Jane, for thy husband's sake,
And every morning when thou pullest them on,
Remember me, and pray for my return,
Make much of them, for I have made them so,
That I can know them from a thousand more.
sp.stage: Sound drum, enter lord Maior, Lincoln, Lacy, Askew, Dodger, and soldiers, they pass over the stage, Rafe falls in amongst them, Firke and the rest cry farewell, etc. and so exeunt.
Enter Rose alone making a garland.
sp.l: Here sit thou down upon this flowery bank,
And make a garland for thy Lacy's head,
These pinks, these roses, and these violets,
These blushing gillyflowers, these marigolds,
The fair embroidery of his coronet,
Carry not half such beauty in their cheeks,
As the sweet countenance of my Lacy doth.
O my most unkind father! O my stars!
Why powered you so at my nativity,
To make me love, yet live robbed of my love?
Here as a thief am I imprisoned
(For my dear Lacy's sake) within those walls,
Which by my father's cost were builded up
For better purposes: here must I languish
For him that doth as much lament (I know)Enter Sibil.
Mine absence, as for him I pine in woe.

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: Good morrow young mistress, I am sure you make that garland for me, against I shall be lady of the harvest.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.p: Sibyl, what news at London?

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: None but good: my lord mayor your father, and master Philpot your uncle, and master Scot your cousin, and mistress Frigbottom by doctors commons, do all (By my troth) send you most hearty commendations.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.p: Did Lacy send kind greetings to his love?

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p:
O yes, out of cry, by my troth, I scant knew him, here 'a wore scarf, and here a scarf, here a bunch of feathers,
and here precious stones and jewels, and a pair of garters: oh monstrous like one of our yellow silk curtains, at home here in Old-ford house, here in master Bellymount's chamber, I stood at our door in Cornhill, looked at him, he at me indeed, spoke to him, but he not to me, not a word, marry guy thought I with a wanion, he passed by me as proud, marry foh, are you grown humorous thought I? and so shut the door, and in I came.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.l: O Sibyl, how dost thou my Lacy wrong?
My Rowland is as gentle as a lamb,
No dove was ever half so mild as he.

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: Mild? yea, as a bushel of stamped crabs, he looked upon me as sour as verjuice: go thy ways thought I, thou mayst be much in my gaskins, but nothing in my netherstocks: this is your fault mistress, to love him that loves not you, he thinks scorn to do as he's done to, but if I were as you, I'd cry, go by Jeronimo, go by, I'd set mine old debts against my new driblets, and the hare's foot against the goose giblets, for if ever I sigh when sleep I should take, pray God I may lose my maidenhead when I wake.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.p: Will my love leave me then and go to France?

sp.speaker: Sibill
sp.p: I know not that, but I am sure I see him stalk before the soldiers, by my troth he is a proper man, but he is proper that proper doth, let him go snick-up young mistress.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.l: Get thee to London, and learn perfectly,
Whether my Lacy go to France, or no:
Do this, and I will give thee for thy pains,
My cambric apron, and my Romish gloves,
My purple stockings, and a stomacher,
Say, wilt thou do this Sibyl for my sake?

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p:
Will I quoth 'a? at whose suit? by my troth yes, I'll go, a cambric apron, gloves, a pair of purple stockings,
and a stomacher, I'll sweat in purple mistress for you, I'll take any thing that comes a god's name, oh rich, a cambric apron; faith then have at up tails all, I'll go, jiggy, jeggy to London, and be here in a trice young mistress. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Do so good Sibyl, mean time wretched I
Will sit and sigh for his lost company. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Rowland Lacy like a Dutch shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: How many shapes have gods and Kings devised,
Thereby to compass their desired loves?
It is no shame for Rowland Lacy then,
To clothe his cunning with the gentle craft,
That thus disguised, I may unknown possess,
The only happy presence of my Rose:
For her have I forsook my charge in France,
Incurred the King's displeasure, and stirred up
Rough hatred in mine uncle Lincoln's breast:
Oh love, how powerful art thou, that canst change
High birth to bareness, and a noble mind,
To the mean semblance of a shoemaker?
But thus it must be: for her cruel father,
Hating the single union of our souls,
Hath secretly conveyed my Rose from London,
To bar me of her presence, but I trust
Fortune and this disguise will further me
Once more to view her beauty, gain her sight.
Here in Towerstreet, with air the shoemaker,
Mean I a while to work, I know the trade,
I learned it when I was in Wittenberg:
Then cheer thy hoping sprites, be not dismayed,
Thou canst not want, do fortune what she can,
The gentle craft is living for a man.Exit.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p:
Where be these boys, these girls, these drabs,
these scoundrels, they wallow in the fat brewis of my bounty, and I lock up the crumbs of my table, yet will not rise to see my walks cleansed: come out you powder-beef-queen, what Nan, what Madge-mumble-crust, come out you fat midriff-swag, belly-whores, and sweep me these kennels, that the noisome stench offend not the nose of my neighbours: what Firk I say, what Hodge? open my shop windows, what Firk I say. Enter Firke.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: O master, is't you that speak bandog and bedlam this morning, I was in a dream, and mused what mad man was got into the street so early, have you drunk this morning that your throat is so clear?

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Ah well said Firk, well said Firk, to work my fine knave, to work, wash thy face, and thou t be more blessed.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Let them wash my face that will eat it, good master send for a souse wife, if you'll have my face cleaner.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Away sloven, avaunt scoundrel, good morrow Hodge, good morrow my fine foreman.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: O master, good morrow, you're an early stirrer, here's a fair morning, good morrow Firk, I could have slept this hour, here's a brave day towards.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: O haste to work my fine foreman, haste to work.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Master I am dry as dust, to hear my fellow Roger talk of fair weather, let us pray for good leather, and let clowns and plowboyes, and those that work in the fields, pray for brave days, we work in a dry shop, what care I if it rain?Enter Eyre's wife.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: How now dame Margery, can you see to rise? trip and go, call up the drabs your maids.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
See to rise? I hope 'tis time enough, 'tis early enough for any woman to be seen abroad, I marvel how many wives in Towerstreet are up so soon? God's me, 'tis not noon,
here's a yawling.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace Margery, peace, where's Cisty Bumtrinket your maid? she has a privy fault, she farts in her sleep, call the quean up, if my men want shooethréed, I'll swinge her in a stirrup.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Yet that's but a dry beating, here's still a sign of drought.Enter Lacy singing.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Der was e'en boar van Gelderland, frolic ū byen,
He was all's drunk he cold nyet stand, upsolce se byen,
Tap eens de canneken drink scheve mannekin.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Master, for my life yonder's a brother of the gentle craft, if he bear not saint Hugh's bones, I'll forfeit my bones, he's some uplandish workman, hire him good master, that I may learn some gibble-gabble , 'twill make us work the faster.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace Firk, a hard world, let him pass, let him vanish, we have journeymen enough, peace my fine Firk.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay, nay, y' are best follow your man's council, you shall see what will come on t: we have not men enough, but we must entertain every butterbox: but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Dame, fore God if my master follow your counsel, he'll consume little beef, he shall be glad of men and he can catch them.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: I that he shall.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Fore God a proper man, and I warrant a fine workman: master farewell, dame adieu, if such a man as he cannot find work, Hodge is not for you.Offer to go.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Stay my fine Hodge.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Faith, and your foreman go, dame you must take a journey to seek a new journeyman, if Roger remove, Firk follows, if s. Hugh's bones shall not be set a work, I may prick mine awl in the walls, and go play: fare ye well master, God buy dame.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Carry my fine Hodge, my brisk foreman, stay Firk, peace pudding broth, by the lord of Ludgate I love my men as my life, peace you gallimaufry, Hodge if he want work I'll hire him, one of you to him, stay, he comes to us.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Eoeden dach meester, end v vro oak.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Nay is if I should speak after him without drinking, I should choke, and you friend oak are you of the gentle craft?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Yaw yaw, ik been den skomawker.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Den skomaker quoth 'a, and hark you skomaker, have you all your tools, a good rubbing pin, a good stopper, a good dresser, your four sorts of awls and your two balls of wax, your paring knife, your hand and thumb-leathers, and good s. Hugh's bones to smooth up your work.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Yaw yaw be niet vor veard, ik hab all de dingen, voour mack shoes groot and clean.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Ha ha good master hire him, he'll make me laugh so that I shall work more in mirth, than I can in earnest.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: I care ye friend, have ye any skill in the mystery of cordwainers?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Ik wéet niet wat ye seg ich vestaw you niet.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Why thus man, ich verste v niet quoth a.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Yaw, yaw, yaw, ick can dat well doen.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Yaw, yaw, he speaks yawing like a Jack daw, that gapes to be fed with cheese curds, oh he'll give a villainous pull at a can of double beer, but Hodge and I have the vantage, we must drink first, because we are the eldest journeyman.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Hans, Hans, Meulter.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, th' art welcome, Hodge entertain him, Fyrk bid him welcome, come Hans, run wife, bid your maids, your crullibubs, make ready my fine men's breakfasts: to him Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Hans, thou'rt welcome, use thyself friendly, for we are good fellows, if not thou shalt be fought with, wert thou bigger than a giant.

sp.speaker: Fyrk.
sp.p: Yea and drunk with, wert thou Gargantua, my master keeps no cowards, I tell thee: he, boy, bring him an heel-block, here's a new journeyman.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Oich wersto, you ich moet een halve dozen cans betaelen: here boy nempt dis skilling, tap eens fréelicke.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Quick snipper-snapper , away Fyrk, scour thy throat, thou shalt wash it with Casulian liquour, come my last of the fives, give me a can, have toEnter boy.thee Hans, here Hodge, here Fyrk, drink you mad Greeks, and work like true Trojans, and pray for Simon Eyre the shoemaker: here Hans, and thou'rt welcome.

sp.speaker: Fyrk.
sp.p: Lo dame you would have lost a good fellow that will teach us to laugh, this beer came hopping in well.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Simon it is almost seven.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Is't so dame clapper dudgeon, is't seven o'clock , and my men's breakfast not ready? trip and go ye soused cunger, away, come you mad Hiperboreans, follow me Hodge, follow me Hans, come after my fine Fyrk, to work, to work a while and then to breakfast. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fyrk.
sp.p: Soft, yaw, yaw, good Hans, though my master have no more wit, but to call you afore me, I am not so foolish to go behind you, I being the elder journeyman.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Warner, and Hammon, like hunters.

sp.speaker: Hammon.
sp.l: Cousin, beat every brake, the game's not far,
This may with winged feet he fled from death,
Whilst the pursuing hounds scenting his steps:
Find out his high way to destruction,
besides, the miller's boy told me even now,
He saw him take sail, and he hallowed him,
Affirming him so embossed,
That long he could not hold.

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.l: If it be so,
'Tis best we trace these meadows by old ford.

div.stage: A noise of hunters within, enter a boy.

sp.speaker: Hammon.
sp.p: How now boy, where's the dear? speak, sawest thou him?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O, yea I saw him scape through a hedge, and then over a ditch, then at my lord majors pale, over he skipped me and in he went me, and holla the hunters cried, and there boy there boy, but there he is a mine honesty.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Boy God a-mercy, cousin let's away,
I hope we shall find better sport today. Exeunt.

div.stage: Hunting within, enter Rose, and Sibill.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Why Sibyl wilt thou prove a forester?

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: Upon some no, forester, go by: no faith mistress, the dear came running into the barn through the orchard, and over the pale, I wot well, I looked as pale as a new cheese to see him, but whip says goodman pin-close, up with his flail, and our nick with a prong, and down he fell, and they upon him, and I upon them, by my troth we had such sport, and in the end we ended him, his throat we cut, flayed him, unhorned him, and my lord maior shall eat of him anon when he comes.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Hark hark, the hunters come, you're best take heed
They'll have a saying to you for this deed.

div.stage: Enter Hammon, Warner, huntsmen, and boy.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: God save you fair ladies.

sp.speaker: Sibil.
sp.p: Ladies, oh gross!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Came not a buck this way?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: No, but two does.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And which way went they? faith we'll hunt at those

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: At those? upon some no: when, can you tell?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Upon some, I.

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: Good lord!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wounds then farewell.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Boy, which way went he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: This way sir he ran.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: This way he ran indeed, fair mistress Rose,
Our game was lately in your orchard seen.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Can you advise which way he took his flight?

sp.speaker: Sibil.
sp.p: Follow your nose, his horns will guide you right.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Thou'rt a mad wench.

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: O rich!

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Trust me, not I,
It is not like the wild forest dear,
Would come so near to places of resort,
You are deceived, he fled some other way.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Which way my sugar-candy, can you show?

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: Come up good honnisops, upon some, no.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Why do you stay, and not pursue your game?

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: I'll hold my life their hunting nags be lame.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: A dear, more dear is found within this place.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: But not the deer (Sir) which you had in chase.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I chased the dear, but this deer chaseth me.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: The strangest hunting that ever I see,
But where's your park?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: 'Tis here: oh stay.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Impale me, and then I will not stray.

sp.speaker: Vvar
sp.p: They wrangle wench, we are more kind than they

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: What kind of heart is that (Dear heart) you seek?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: A heart, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Sibil.
sp.p: whoever saw the like?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: To lose your heart, is't possible you can?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: My heart is lost.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Alack good gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: This poor lost heart would I with you might find.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: You by such luck might prove your heart a hind.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Why luck had horns, so have I heard some say.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Now God and't be his will send luck into your way.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.p: What m. Hammon, welcome to old ford.

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: God's pittikins, hands off sir, here's my lord.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.p: I hear you had ill luck, and lost your game.

sp.speaker: Hammon.
sp.p: 'Tis true my lord.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: I am sorry for the same.
What gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Hammon.
sp.p: My brother in law.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: Y' are welcome both, sith fortune offers you
Into my hands, you shall not part from hence,
Until you have refreshed your wearied limbs:
Go Sibyl cover the board, you shall be guest
To no good cheer, but even a hunter's feast.

sp.speaker: Hammon.
sp.l: I thank your lordship: cousin, on my life
For our lost venison, I shall find a wife.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: In gentlemen, I'll not be absent long.
This Hammon is a proper gentleman,
A citizen by birth, fairly allied,
How fit an husband were he for my girl?
Well, I will in, and do the best I can,
To match my daughter to this gentléman.Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lacy, skipper, Hodge, and Firke.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p:
Ick sal ye what seggen Hans, dis skip dat comen from Candy is all wol, by gets sacrament, van sugar, civet,
almonds, cambric, end all dingen tousand tousand ding, nempt it Hans, nempt it voz v meester, daer be de bills van laden, your meester Simon Eyre sal hae good copen, wat seggen ye Hans?

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: Wat seggen de reggen de copen, slopen, laugh Hodge laugh.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.p: Mine liever brother firk, bringt meester Eyre lot den sign un swannekin, daer sal ye find dis skipper end me, wat seggen ye brother firk? do't it Hodge, come skipper.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Bring him quoth. you, here's no knavery, to bring me master to buy a ship, worth the lading of 2 or 3 hundred thousand pounds, alas that's nothing, a trifle, a babble Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hod
sp.p: The truth is Firk, that the merchant owner of the ship dares not show his head, and therefore this skipper that deals for him, for the love he bears to Hans, offers my master Eyre a bargain in the commodities, he shall have a reasonable day of payment, he may sell the wares by that time, and be an huge gainer himself.

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: Yea, but can my fellow Hans lend my master twenty porpentines as an earnest penny.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Portagues thou wouldst say, here they be Firke, hark, they jingle in my pocket like s. Mary queries bells.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Mum, here comes my dame and my master, she'll scold on my life, for loitering this Monday, but all's one, let them all say what they can, monday's our holiday.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You sing sir sauce, but I beshrew your heart,
I fear for this your singing we shall smart.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Smart for me dame, why dame, why?

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: Master I hope you'll not suffer my dame to take down your journeymen.

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p:
If she take me down, I'll take her up, yea and take
her down too, a button, hole lower.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace Firk, not I Hodge, by the life of Pharaoh, by the lord of Ludgate, by this beard, every hair whereof I value at a King's ransom, she shall not meddle with you, peace you bombast-cotton-candle quean, away Queen of clubs, quarrel not with me and my men, with me and my fine Firk, I'll firk you if you do.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yea, yea man, you may use me as you please: but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Let it pass, let it vanish away: peace, am I not Simon Eyre? are not these my brave men? brave shoemakers, all gentlemen of the gentle craft? prince am I none, yet am I nobly born, as being the sole son of a shoemaker, away rubbish, vanish, melt, melt like kitchen stuff.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yea, yea, 'tis well, I must be called rubbish, kitchen stuff, for a sort of knaves.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Nay dame, you shall not weep and wail in woe for me: master I'll stay no longer, here's a inventory of my shop tools: adieu master, Hodge farewell.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Nay stay Firk, thou shalt not go alone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I pray let them go, there be more maids than malkin, more men than Hodge, and more fools than Firk.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Fool's? nails if I tarry now, I would my guts might be turned to shoe-thread.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: And if I stay, I pray God I may be turned to a Turk, and set in Finsbury for boys to shoot at: come firk.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p:
Stay my fine knaves, you arms of my trade, you pillars of my profession. What, shall a tittle tattles words make you forsake Simon Eyre? avaunt kitchenstuff, rip you brown bread tannakin, out of my sight, move me not, have not I ta'en you from selling tripes in Eastcheap, and set you in my shop, and made you hail fellow with
Simon Eyre the shoemaker? and now do you deal thus with my journeymen? Look you powder beef quean on the face of Hodge, here's a face for a lord.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: And here's a face for any lady in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Rip you chitterling, avaunt boy, bid the tapster of the boar's head fill me a dozen cans of beer for my journeymen.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: A dozen cans? O brave, Hodge now I'll stay.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: And the knave fills any more than two, he pays for them: a dozen cans of beer for my journeymen, hear you mad Mesopotamians, wash your livers with this liquor, where be the odd ten? no more Madge, no more, well said, drink and to work: what work dost thou Hodge? what work?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: I am a making a pair of shoes for my lord mayor's daughter, mistress Rose.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: And I a pair of shoes for Sibyl my lord's maid, I deal with her.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Sibyl? fie, defile not thy fine workmanly fingers with the feet of kitchenstuff, and basting ladies, ladies of the court, fine ladies, my lads, commit their feet to our apparelling, put gross work to Hans; yerk and seam, yerk and seam.

sp.speaker: Fyrk.
sp.p: For yarking and seeming let me alone, and I come to't.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Well master, all this is from the bias, do you remember the ship my fellow Hans told you of, the skipper and he are both drinking at the swan? here be the portuguese to give earnest, if you go through with it, you can not choose but be a lord at least.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Nay dame, if my master prove not a lord, and you a lady, hang me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yea like enough, if you may loiter and tipple thus.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p:
Tipple dame? no, we have been bargaining with Skellum skanderbag: can you Dutch spreaken for a ship of
silk cypress, laden with sugar Candy.

div.stage: Enter the boy with a velvet coat, and an alderman's gown. Air puts it on.

sp.speaker: Eire.
sp.p: Peace firk, silence tittle tattle: Hodge, I'll go through with it, here's a seal ring, and I have sent for a guarded gown, and a damask cassock, see where it comes, look here Maggy, help me firk, apparreline Hodge, silk and satin you mad Philistines, silk and satin.

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: Ha, ha, my master will be as proud as a dog in a doublet, all in beaten damask and velvet.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Softly Firk, for rearing of the nap, and wearing threadbare my garments: how dost thou like me Firk? how do I look, my fine Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Why now you look like your selfmaster, I warrant you, there's few in the city, but will give you the wall, and come upon you with the right worshipful.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Nails my master looks like a threadbare cloak new turned, and dressed: lord, lord, to see what good raiment both? dame, dame, are you not enamoured?

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: How sayest thou Maggy, am I not brisk? am I not fine?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Fine? by my troth sweet heart very fine: by my troth I never liked thee so well in my life sweet heart. But let that pass, I warrant there be many women in the city have not such handsome husbands, but only for their apparel, but let that pass too. Enter Hans and Skipper.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: God-den day mester, dis be de skipper dat heb de skip van merchandise de commodity been good, nempt it master, nempt it.

sp.speaker: Aire.
sp.p: Godamercy Hans, welcome skipper, where lies this ship of merchandise?

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: De skip ben in rovere: dor be van sugar, civet, almonds, cambric, and a tousand tousand tings, God's sacrament, nempt it mester, yo sal heb good copen.

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: To him master, oh sweet master, oh sweet wares, prunes, almons, sugar-candy, carrat roots, turnips, oh brave fatting meat, let not a man buy a nutmeg but yourself.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Peace Firk, come skipper, I'll go abroad with you, Hans have you made him drink?

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Yaw, yaw, it heb veale ge drunk.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Come Hans follow me: skipper, thou shalt have my countenance in the city. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Yaw heb veale ge drunk, quoth 'a: they may well be called butter-boxes, when they drink fat veal, and thick bear too: but come dame, I hope you'll chide us no more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No faith Firk, no perdie Hodge, I do feel honour creep upon me, and which is more, a certain rising in my flesh, but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Rising in your flesh do you feel say you? I you may be with child, but why should not my master feel a rising in his flesh, having a gown and a gold ring on, but you are such a shrew, you'll soon pull him down.

sp.speaker: Vvi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, prithee peace, thou mak'st my worship laugh, but let that pass: come I'll go in Hodge, prithee go before me, Firk follow me.

sp.speaker: Fi.
sp.p: Firk doth follow, Hodge pass out in state. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: How now good Dodger, what's the news in France?

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.l: My lord, upon the eighteen day of May,
The French and English were prepared to fight,
Each side with eager fury gave the sign
Of a most hot encounter, five long hours
Both armies fought together: at the length,
The lot of victory fell on our sides,
Twelve thousand of the Frenchmen that day died,
Four thousand English, and no man of name,
But captain Hyam, and young Ardington,
two gallant gentlemen, I knew them well.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: But Dodger, prithee tell me in this fight,
How did my cousin Lacy bear himself?

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: My lord, your cousin Lacy was not there.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Not there? Dog. No, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Sure thou mistakest,
I saw him shipped, and a thousand eyes beside
Were witnesses of the farewells which he gave,
When I with weeping eyes bid him adieu:
Dodger take heed.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.l: My lord I am advised,
That what I spoke is true: to prove it so,
His cousin askew that supplied his place,
Sent me for him from France, that secretly
He might convey himself hither.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Is't even so.
Dares he so carelessly venture his life,
Upon the indignation of a King?
Hath he despised my love, and spurned those favours,
Which I with prodigal hand poured on his head?
He shall repent his rashness with his soul,
Since of my love he makes no estimate,
I'll make him wish he had not known my hate,
Thou hast no other news?

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: None else, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: None worse I know thou hast: procure the King
To crown his giddy brows with ample honours,
Send him chief colonel, and all my hope
Thus to be dashed? but 'tis in vain to grieve,
One evil cannot a worse relieve:
Upon my life I have found out his plot,
That old dog love that fawned upon him so,
Love to that puling girl, his fair cheeked rose,
the lord mayor's daughter hath distracted him,
And in the fire of that love's lunacy,
Hath he burned up himself, consumed his credit,
Lost the King's love, yea and I fear, his life,
Only to get a wanton to his wife:
Dodger, it is so.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: I fear so, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Lincoln.
sp.l: It is so, nay sure it cannot be,
I am at my wit's end Dodger.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: Yea my lord.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Thou art acquainted with my nephew's haunts,
Spend this gold for thy pains, go seek him out,
Watch at my lord majors (There if he live)
Dodger, thou shalt be sure to meet with him:
Prithee be diligent. Lacy thy name
Lived once in honour, now dead in shame:
Be circumspect.Exit.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: I warrant you my lord.Exit.

div.stage: Enter lord Maior, and master Scotte.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: Good master Scot, I have been bold with you,
To be a witness to a wedding knot,
Betwixt young master Hammon and my daughter,
Oh stand aside, see where the lovers come.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.l: Can it be possible you love me so?
No, no, within those eyeballs I espy,
Apparent likelihoods of flattery,
Pray now let go my hand.

sp.speaker: Hammon.
sp.l: Sweet mistress Rose,
Misconstrue not my words, nor misconceive
Of my affection, whose devoted soul
Swears that I love thee dearer than my heart.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: As dear as your own heart? I judge it right.
Men love their hearts best when they're out of sight.

sp.speaker: Hamond.
sp.p: I love you, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Yet hands off now:
If flesh be frail, how weak and frail's your vow?

sp.speaker: Hamond.
sp.p: Then by my life I swear.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Then do not brawl,
One quarrel loseth wife and life and all,
Is not your meaning thus?

sp.speaker: Hamond.
sp.p: In faith you jest.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Love loves to sport, therefore leave love you're best.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.p: What? square they master Scot?

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.l: Sir, never doubt,
Lovers are quickly in, and quickly out.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sweet Rose, be not so strange in fancying me,
Nay never turn aside, shun not my sight,
I am not grown so fond, to fond my love
On any that shall quit it with disdain,
If you will love me, so, if not, farewell.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Why how now lovers, are you both agreed?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Yes faith my lord.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: 'Tis well, give me your hand, give me yours daughter.
How now, both pull back, what means this, girl?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: I mean to live a maid.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: But not to die one, pause ere that be said.Aside.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.p: Will you still cross me? still be obstinate?

sp.speaker: Hamond.
sp.l: Nay chide her not my lord for doing well,
If she can live an happy virgin's life,
'Tis far more blessed than to be a wife.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Say sir I cannot, I have made a vow,
Whoever be my husband, 'tis not you.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.l: Your tongue is quick, but m. Hamond know,
I bade you welcome to another end.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What, would you have me pule, and pine, and pray,
with lovely lady mistress of my heart,
Pardon your servant, and the rimer play,
Railing on Cupid, and his tyrant's dart,
Or that I undertake some martial spoil,
Wearing your glove at tourney, and at tilt,
And tell how many gallauts I unhorsed,
Sweet, will this pleasure you?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Yea, when wilt begin?
What love-rhymes man? fie on that deadly sin.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.p: If you will have her, I'll make her agree.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Enforced love is worse than hate to me,
There is a wench keeps shop in the old change,
To her will I, it is not wealth I seek,
I have enough, and will prefer her love
Before the world: my good lord mayor adieu,
Old love for me, I have no luck with new.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: Now mammet you have well behaved yourself,
But you shall curse your coins if I live,
Who's within there? see you convey your mistress
Straight to th'old ford, I'll keep you straight enough,
Fore God I would have sworn the puling girl,
Would willingly accepted Hamon's love,
But banish him my thoughts, go minion in,Exit Rose.
Now tell me master Scot would you have thought,
That master Simon Eyre the shoemaker,
Had been of wealth to buy such merchandise?

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.l: 'Twas well my lord, your honour, and myself,
Grew partners with him for your bills of lading,
Show that Eyre's gains in one commodity,
Rise at the least to full thrée thousand pound,
Besides like gain in other merchandise.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: Well he shall spend some of his thousands now
for I have sent for him to the guild hal,Enter Eyre.
See where he comes: good morrow master Eyre.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Poor Simon Eyre, my lord, your shoemaker.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: Well well, it likes yourself to term you so,
Now m. Dodger, what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: I'd gladly speak in private to your honour.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: You shall, you shall: master Eyre, and m. Scot,
I have some business with this gentleman,
I pray let me entreat you to walk before
To the guild hal, I'll follow presently,
Master Eyre, I hope ere noon to call you sheriff.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: I would not care (My lord) if you might call me King of Spain, come master Scot.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.p: Now master Dodger, what's the news you bring?

sp.speaker: Dod.
sp.l: The Earl of Lincoln by me greets your lordship
And earnestly requests you (If you can)
Inform him where his nephew Lacy keeps.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.p: Is not his nephew Lacy now in France?

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: No I assure your lordship, but disguised lurks here in London.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: London? is't even so?
It may be, but upon my faith and soul,
I know not where he lives, or whether he lives,
So tell my lord of Lincoln, lurch in London?
Well master Dodger, you perhaps may start him,
Be but the means to ris him into France,
I'll give you a dozen angels for your pains,
So much I love his honour, hate his nephew,
And prithee so inform thy lord from me.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: I take my leave.Exit. Dodger.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: Farewell good master Dodger.
Lacy in London? I dare pawn my life,
My daughter knows thereof, and for that cause,
Denied young m. Hammon in his love,
Well I am glad I sent her to old Ford,
God's lord 'tis late, to Guild-hall I must hie,
I know my brothers stay my company.Exit.

div.stage: Enter Firke, Eyre's wife, Hans, and Roger.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thou goest too fast for me Roger.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I pray thee run (Do you hear) run to Guild-hall , and learn if my husband master Eyre will take that worshipful vocation of m. sheriff upon him, hie thee good Firke.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Take it? well I go, and he should not take it, firk swears to forswear him, yes forsooth I go to Guild-hall .

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay when? thou art too compendious, and tedious.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: O rare, your excellence is full of eloquence, how like a new cart wheel my dame speaks, and she looks like an old musty ale-bottle going to scalding.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay when? thou wilt make me melancholy.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: God forbid your worship should fall into that humour, I run.Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let me see now Roger and Hans.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I forsooth dame (Mistress I should say) but the old term so sticks to the roof of my mouth, I can hardly lick it off.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Even what thou wilt good Roger, dame is a fair name for any honest christian, but let that pass, how dost thou Hans?

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Me tanck you uro.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Well Hans and Roger you see God hath blessed your master, and perdie if ever he comes to be m. sheriff of London (As we are all mortal) you shall see I will have some odd thing or other in a corner for you: I will not be your
back friend, but let that pass, Hans pray thee tie my shoe.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yaw it sal vro.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Roger, thou knowest the length of my foot, as it is none of the biggest, so I thank God it is handsome enough, prithee let me have a pair of shoes made, cork good Roger, wooden heel too.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Art thou acquainted with never a farthingale-maker, nor a french-hood maker, I must enlarge my bumine, ha ha, how shall I look in a hood I wonder? perdie oddly I think.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: As a cat out of a pillory, very well I warrant you mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Indeed all flesh is grass, and Roger, canst thou tell where I may buy a good hair?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, at the poulterers in gracious street.

sp.speaker: Vvi.
sp.p: Thou art an ungracious wag, perdie, I mean a false hair for my periwig.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Why mistress, the next time I cut my beard, you shall have the shavings of it, but they are all true hairs.

sp.speaker: Vvi.
sp.p: It is very hot, I must get me a fan or else a mask.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: So you had need, to hide your wicked face.

sp.speaker: Vvi.
sp.p: Fie upon it, how costly this world's calling is, perdie, but that it is one of the wonderful works of God, I would not deal with it: is not Firk come yet? Hans been not so sad, let it pass and vanish, as my husband's worship says.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Ick been vrolicke, lot see ye so.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Mistress, will you drink a pipe of tobacco?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O fie upon it Roger, perdie, these filthy tobacco pipes are the most idle slavering babbles that ever I felt: out upon it, God bless us, men look not like men that use them.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: What fellow Rafe? Mistress look here, Jane's husband, why how, lame? Hans make much of him, he's a brother of our trade, a good workman, and a tall soldier.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: You be welcome brother.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Perdie I knew him not, how dost thou good Rafe? I am glad to see thee well.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: I would god you saw me dame as well,
As when I went from London into France.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Trust me I am sorry Rafe to see thee impotent, lord how the wars have made him sunburnt: the left leg is net well it was a fair gift of God the infirmity took not hold a little higher, considering thou camest from France: but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: I am glad to see you well, and I rejoice
To hear that God hath blessed my master so
Since my departure.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yea truly Rafe, I thank my maker: but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And sirrah Rafe, what news, what news in France?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Tell me good Roger first, what news in England?
Haw does my Jane? when didst thou see my wife?
Where lives my poor heart? she'll be poor indeed
Now I want limbs to get whereon to feed.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Limbs? hast thou not hands man? thou shalt never see a shoemaker want bread, though he have but thrée fingers on a hand.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Yet all this while I hear not of my Jane.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
O Rafe your wife, perdie we know not what's become of her: she was here a while, and because she was married grew more stately than became her, I checked her, and so forth, away she flung, never returned, nor said bih
nor bah: and Rafe you know ka me, ka thee. And so as I tell ye. Roger is not Firk come yet?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: No forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And so indeed we heard not of her, but I hear she lives in London: but let that pass. If she had wanted, she might have opened her case to me or my husband, or to any of my men, I am sure there's not any of them perdie, but would have done her good to his power. Hans look if Firk be come.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yaw it sal vro.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And so as I said: but Rafe, why dost thou weep? thou knowest that naked we came out of our mother's womb, and naked we must return, and therefore thank God for all things.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: No faith Jane is a stranger here, but Rafe pull up a good heart, I know thou hast one, thy wife man, is in London, one told me he saw her a while ago very brave and neat, we'll ferret her out, and London hold her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Alas, poor soul, he's overcome with sorrow, he does but as I do, weep for the loss of any good thing: but Rafe, get thee in, call for some meat and drink, thou shalt find me worshipful towards thee.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: I thank you dame, since I want limbs and lands,
I'll to God, my good friends, and to these my hands.

sp.speaker: Fyrke.
sp.p:
Run good Hans, oh Hodge, oh mistress, Hodge. heave up thine ears, mistress smug up your looks, on
with your best apparel, my master is chosen, my master is called nay condemned by the cry of the country to be sheriff of the city, for this famous year now to come: and time now being, a great many men in black gowns were asked for their voices, and their hands, and my master had all their fists about his ears presently, and they cried I, ay, ay, ay, and so I came away, wherefore without all other grieve, I do salute you mistress shrieve.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yaw, my mester is de groot man, de shrieve.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Did not I tell you mistress? now I may boldly say, good morrow to your worship.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good morrow good Roger, I thank you my good people all. Firk, hold up thy hand, here's a threepenny piece for thy tidings.

sp.speaker: Fyrk.
sp.p: 'Tis but thrée half pence, I think: yes, 'tis thrée pence, I smell the rose.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But mistress, be ruled by me, and do not speak so pulingly.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: 'Tis her worship speaks so, and not she, no faith mistress, speak me in the old key, too it Firk, there good Firke, ply your business Hodge, Hodge, with a full mouth: I'll fill your bellies with good cheer till they cry twang.

div.stage: Enter Simon Eire wearing a gold chain.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: See mine liever brother, here count my meester.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Welcome home master shrieve, I pray God continue you in health and wealth.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p:
See here my Maggy, a chain, a gold chain for Simon Eyre, I shall make thee a lady, here's a French hood for thee, on with it, on with it, dress thy brows with this flap of a shoulder of mutton, to make thee look lovely: where be my fine men? Roger, I'll make over my shop and tools to thee: Firk, thou shalt be the foreman: Hans, thou shalt
have an hundred for twenty, be as mad knaves as your master Sim Eyre hath been, and you shall live to be sheriffs of London: how dost thou like me Margery? Prince am I none, yet am I princely born, Firk, Hodge, and Hans.

sp.speaker: Al●.
sp.p: I forsooth, what says your worship mistress sheriff?

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Worship and honour you Babylonian knaves, for the gentle craft: but I forgotten myself, I am bidden by my lord mayor to dinner to old Foord, he's gone before, I must after: come Hodge, on with your trinkets: now my true 〈◊〉, my fine Firk, my dapper Hodge, my honest Hans, some device, some odd crochets, some morris, or such like, for the honour of the gentle shoemakers, meet me at old Foord, you know my mind: come Madge, away shut up the shop knaves, and make holiday. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.l: O rare, oh brave, come Hodge, follow me Hans,
We'll be with them for a morris dance.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter lord Maior, Eyre, his wife, Sibill in a French hood, and other servants.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.p: Trust me you are as welcome to old Foord, as I myself.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Truly I thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Would our bad cheer were worth the thanks you give.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Good cheer my lord mayor, fine cheer, a fine house, fine walls, all fine and neat.

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: Now by my troth I'll tell thee master Eyre,
It does me good and all my brothers,
That such a madcap fellow as thyself
Is entered into our society.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I but my lord, he must learn now to put on gravity.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p:
Peace Maggy, a fig for gravity, when I go to Guildhall in my scarlet gown, I'll look as demurely as a saint, and
speak as gravely as a justice of peace, but now I am here at old Foord, at my good lord mayor's house, let it go by, vanish Maggy, I'll be merry, away with flip flap, these fooleries, these gulleries: what honey? prince am I none, yet am I princely born: what says my lord maior?

sp.speaker: L. mayor.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I had rather than a thousand pound,
I had an heart but half so light as yours.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: Why what should I do my lord? A pound of care pays not a dram of debt: hum, let's be merry whiles we are young, old age, sack and sugar will steal upon us ere we be aware.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: It's well done mistress Eyre, pray give good counsel to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I hope mistress Rose will have the grace to take nothing that's bad.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: Pray God she do, for i'faith mistress Eyre,
I would bestow upon that peevish girl
A thousand marks more than I mean to give her,
Upon condition she'd be ruled by me,
The ape still crosseth me: there came of late,
A proper gentleman of fair revenues,
Whom gladly I would call son in law:
But my fine cockney would have none of him.
You'll prove a coxcomb for it ere you die,
A courtier, or no man must please your eye.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p:
Be ruled sweet Rose, thou'rt ripe for a man: marry not with a boy, that has no more hair on his face than thou hast on thy cheeks: a courtier, wash, go by, stand not upon pishery-pashery : those silken fellows are but painted images, outsides, outsides Rose, their inner linings are torn: no my fine mouse, marry me with a gentleman grocer like my lord maior your father, a grocer is a sweet trade, plums, plums: had I a son or daughter should marry
out of the generation and blood of the shoemakers, he should pack: what, the gentle trade is a living for a man through Europe, through the world.

div.stage: Anoyse within of a taber and a pipe.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: What noise is this?

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: O my lord mayor, a true of good fellows that for love to your honour, are come hither with a morris-dance, come in my Mesopotamians cheerly.

div.stage: Enter Hodge, Hans, Raph, Firke, and other shooe-makers in a morris: after a little dancing the lord Maior speaks.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: Master Eyre, are all these shoemakers?

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p: All cordwainers my good lord mayor.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: How like my Lacy looks yond shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Haunce.
sp.p: O that I durst but speak unto my love!

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: Sibyl, go fetch some wine to make these drink,
You are all welcome.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.l: We thank your lordship.

div.stage: Rose takes a cup of wine and goes to Haunce.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: For his sake whose fair shape thou representest, good friend I drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: It be dank good frister.

sp.speaker: Eyre's wife.
sp.p: I see mistress Rose you do not want judgement, you have drunk to the properest man I keep.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Here be some have done their parts to be as proper as he.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.l: Well, urgent business calls me back to London:
Good fellows, first go in and taste our cheer,
And to make merry as you homeward go,
Spend these two angels in beer at Stratford Boe.

sp.speaker: Eyre.
sp.p:
To these two (My mad lads) Sim Eyre adds another,
then cheerly Firk, tickle it Haunce, and all for the honour of shoemakers.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: Come master Eyre, let's have your company.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Sibyl what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: That Haunce the shoemaker is my love Lacy,
Disguised in that attire to find me out,
How should I find the means to speak with him?

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: What mistress, never fear, I dare venture my maidenhead to nothing, and that's great odds, that Haunce the Dutchman when we come to London, shall not only see and speak with you, but in spite of all your father's policies, steal you away and marry you, will not this please you?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Do this, and ever be assured of my love.

sp.speaker: Sibil.
sp.l: Away then and follow your father to London, left
Your absence cause him to suspect something:
Tomorrow if my counsel be obeyed,
I'll bind you prentice to the gentle trade.

div.stage: Enter Jane in a sempster's shop working, and Hamond muffled at another door, he stands aloof.

sp.speaker: Hamond.
sp.l: Yonder's the shop, and there my fair love sits,
She's fair and lovely, but she is not mine,
O would she were, thrice have I courted her,
Thrice hath my hand been moistened with her hand,
Whilst my poor famished eyes do feed on that
Which made them famish: I am infortunate,
I still love one, yet nobody loves me,
I muse in other men what women see,
that I so want? fine mistress Rose was coy,
And this too curious, o no, she is chaste,
And for the thinks me wanton, she denies
〈◊〉 cheer my cold heart with her sunny eyes:
How prettily she works, o pretty hand!
O happy work, it doth me good to stand
〈◊〉 to see her, thus I oft have stood,
In frosty evenings, a light burning by her,
Enduring biting cold, only to eye her,
One only look hath seemed as rich to me
As a King's crown, such is love's lunacy:
Muffled I'll pass along, and by that try
Whether she know me.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Sir, what is't you buy?
What is't you lack sir? callico, or lawn,
Fine cambric shirts, or bands, what will you buy?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That which thou wilt not sell, faith yet I'll try:
How do you sell this handkercher?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Good cheap.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And how these ruffs?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Cheap too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And how this band?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Cheap too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: All cheap, how sell you then this hand?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: My hands are not to be sold.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: To be given then: nay faith I come to buy.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: But none knows when.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Good sweet, leave work a little while, let's play.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I cannot live by keeping holiday.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I'll pay you for the time which shall be lost.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: With me you shall not be at so much cost.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Look how you wound this cloth, so you wound me.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: What remedy?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay faith you are too coy.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Let go my hand.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will do any task of your command,
I would let go this beauty, were I not
In mind to disobey you by a power
That controls Kings: I love you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: So, now part.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: With hands I may, but never with my heart,
In faith I love you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I believe you do.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Shall a true love in me breed hate in you?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I hate you not.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Then you must love.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I do, what are you better now? I love not you,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: All this I hope is but a woman's fray,
That means, come to me, when she cries, away:
In earnest mistress I do not jest,
A true chaste love hath entered in my breast,
In love you dear as I love my life,
I love you as a husband loves a wife.
That, and no other love my love requires,
Thy wealth I know is little, my desires
Thirst not for gold, sweet beauteous Jane what's mine,
Shall (If thou make myself thine) all be thine,
Say, judge, what is thy sentence, life or death?
Mercy or cruelty lies in thy breath.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Good sir, I do believe you love me well:
For 'tis a silly conquest, silly pride,
For one like you (I mean a gentleman)
To boast, that by his love tricks he hath brought,
Such and such women to his amorous lure:
I think you do not so, yet many do,
And make it even a very trade to woo,
I could be coy, as many women be,
Feed you with sunshine smiles, and wanton looks,
But I detest witchcraft, say that I
Do constantly believe you, constant have.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Why dost thou not believe me?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I believe you,
But yet good sir, because I will not grieve you,
With hopes to taste fruit, which will never fall,
In simple truth this is the sum of all
My husband lives, at least I hope he lives,
Pressed was he to these bitter wars in France,
Bitter they are to me by wanting him,
I have but one heart, and that hearts his due,
How can I then bestow the same on you?
Whilst he lives, his I live, be it ne'er so poor,
And rather be his wife, than a King's whore.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Chaste and dear woman, I will not abuse thee,
Although it cost my life, if thou refuse me,
Thy husband pressed for France, what was his name?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Rafe Damport.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Damport, here's a letter sent
From France to me, from a dear friend of mine,
A gentleman of place, here he doth write,
Their names that have been slain in every fight.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I hope death's scroll contains not my love's name

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Cannot you read?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I can.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Beruse the same,
To my remembrance such a name I read
Amongst the rest: see here.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Ay me, he's dead:
he's dead, if this be true my dear hearts slain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Have patience, dear love.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Hence, hence.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay sweet Jane,
Make not poor sorrow proud with these rich tears,
I mourn thy husband's death because thou mournest.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: That bill is forged; 'tis signed by forgery.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I'll bring thee letters sent besides to many
Carrying the like report: Jane 'tis too true,
Come, weep not: mourning though it rise from love
Helps not the mourned, yet hurts them that mourn.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: For god's sake leave me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Whither dost thou turn?
Forget the deed, love them that are alive,
His love is faded, try how mine will thrive.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: 'Tis now no time for me to think on love,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: 'Tis now best time for you to think on love, because your love lives not.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Though he be dead, my love to him shall not be buried:
For God's sake leave me to myself alone.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I would kill my soul to leave thee drowned in moan:
Answer me to my suit, and I am gone,
Say to me, yea, or no.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Then farewell, one farewell will not serve, I come again, come dry these wet cheeks, tell me faith sweet Jane, yea, or no, once more.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Once more I say no, once more be gone I pray, else will I go.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay then I will grow rude by this white hand,
Until you change that cold no, here I'll stand,
Till by your hard heart

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Nay, for god's love peace,
my sorrows by your presence more increase,
Not that you thus are present, but all grief
Desires to be alone, therefore in brief
Thus much I say, and saying bid adieu,
If ever I wed man it shall be you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O blessed voice, dear Jane I'll urge no more,
Thy breath hath made me rich.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Death makes me poor.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Hodge at his shop board, Rafe, Firk, Hans, and a boy at work.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Hey down, a down, down derie.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Well said my hearts, ply your work today, we loitered yesterday, to it pell-mell , that we may live to be lord majors, or aldermen at least.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Hey down a down derie.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Well said i'faith, how sayest thou Hauns, doth not Firk tickle it?

sp.speaker: Hauns.
sp.p: Yaw mester.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Not so neither, my organ pipe squeaks this morning for want of liquoring: heigh down a down derie.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Forward Firk, tow best un jolly youngster hort I mester it bid you cut me un pair vāpres warrant mester Jeffer's boots.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Thou shalt haims.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Master.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: How now, boy?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Pray, now you are in the cutting vain, cut me out a pair of counterfeits, or else my work will not pass currant, heigh down a down.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Tell me sirs, are my cousin m. Priscilla's shoes done?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Your cousin? no master, one of your aunts, hang her, let them alone.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p:
I am in hand with them, she gave charge that none
but I should do them for her. 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Thou do for her? than 〈…〉 that she loves not: Rafe, thou n 〈…〉 in faith I would have yerked and 〈…〉 down a down derry, this gear w 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: How sayest thou Firk? were 〈…〉 ford?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: How merry? why our buttocks went jiggy ioggy like a quagmire: well sir Roger Oatemeale, if I thought all meal of that nature, I would eat nothing but bag puddings.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Of all good fortunes, my fellow Hance had the best.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: 'Tis true, because mistress Rose drank to him.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Well, well, work apace, they say seven of the aldermen be dead, or very sick.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: I care not, I'll be none.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: No nor I, but then my m. Eyre will come quickly to be l. mayor. Enter Sibil.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Whoop, yonder comes Sibyl.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Sibyl, welcome i'faith, and how dost thou mad wench?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Sib whore, welcome to London.

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: Godamercy sweet Firke: good lord Hodge, what a delicious shop you have got, you tickle it i'faith.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: God a mercy Sibyl for our good cheer at old ford.

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: That you shall have Rafe.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Nay by the mass, we had tickling cheer Sibyl, and how the plague dost thou and mistress Rose, and my l. mayor? I put the women in first.

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: Well godamercy: but gods me, I forget myself, where's Haunce the fleming?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.l: Hark butterbox, vow you must yely out some spreken.
〈…〉 odd gone frister.
〈…〉 me to my young mistress, to pull
〈…〉 le fro, vare ben your mistress?
〈…〉 our London house in Cornwall
〈…〉 serve her turn but Hans?
〈…〉 come Hans, I stand upon needles.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: Why then Sibyl, take heed of pricking.

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: For that let me alone, I have a trick in my budget, come Hans.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yaw, yaw, ic sall meet yo gane.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Go Hans, make haste again: come, who lacks work?

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: I master, for I lack my breakfast, 'tis munching time, and past

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Is't so? why then leave work Raph, to breakfast, boy look to the tools, come Raph, come Firk. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Let me see now, the sign of the last in Towerstreet, mass yonder's the house: what haw, who's within?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Who calls there, what want you sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Marry I would have a pair of shoes made for a gentlewoman against tomorrow morning, what can you do them?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Yes sir, you shall have them, but what lengths her foot?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Why you must make them in all parts like this shoe, but at any hand fail not to do them, for the gentlewoman is to be married very early in the morning.

sp.speaker: Raph
sp.p: How? by this shoe must it be made? by this, are you sure sir by this?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: How, by this am I sure, by this? art thou in thy wits? I tell thee I must have a pair of shoes, dost thou mark me? A pair of shoes, two shoes, made by this very shoe, this same shoe, against tomorrow morning by four o'clock , dost understand me, canst thou do't?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Yes sir, yes, ay, ay, I can do't, by this shoe you say: I should know this shoe, yes sir, yes, by this shoe, I can do t, four o'clock , well, whither shall I bring them?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: To the sign of the golden ball in Watlingstreet, inquire for one master Hamon a gentleman, my master.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Yea sir, by this shoe you say.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I say master Hammon at the golden ball, he's the bridegroom, and those shoes are for his bride.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: They shall be done by this shoe: well, well, master Hammon at the golden shoe, I would say the golden ball, very well, very well, but I pray you sir where must master Hammon be married?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: At saint faith's church under Paul's: but what's that to thee? prithee dispatch those shoes, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: By this shoe said he, how am I amazed
At this strange accident? upon my life,
This was the very shoe I gave my wife
When I was pressed for France, since when alas,
I never could hear of her: it is the same,
And Hamon's bride no other but my Jane.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Snails Raph thou hast lost thy part of thrée pots, a countryman of mine gave me to breakfast.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: I care not, I have found a better thing.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: A thing? away, is it a man's thing, or a woman's thing?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Firk, dost thou know this shoe?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: No by my troth, neither doth that know me? I have no acquaintance with it, 'tis a mere stranger to me.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.l: Why then I do, this shoe I durst be sworn
Once covered the instep of my Jane:
This is her size, her breadth, thus trod my love,
These true love knots I pricked, I hold my life,
By this old shoe I shall find out my wife.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Ha ha old shoe, that wert new, how a murrain came this ague fit of foolishness upon thee?

sp.speaker: Rafe
