sp.l: Thus Firk, even now here came a servingman,
By this shoe would he have a new pair made
Against tomorrow morning for his mistress,
That's to be married to a gentleman,
And why may not this be my sweet Jane?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: And why mayst not thou be my sweet ass? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.l: Well, laugh, and spare not: but the truth is this.
Against tomorrow morning I'll provide,
A lusty crew of honest shoemakers,
To watch the going of the bride to church,
If she prove Jane, I'll take her in despite,
From Hammon and the devil, were he by,
If it be not my Jane, what remedy?
Hereof am I sure, I shall live till I die,
Although I never with a woman lie.Exit.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.p: Thou he with a woman to build nothing but Cripplegates! Well, God sends fools fortune, and it may be he may light upon his matrimony by such a device, for wedding and hanging goes by destiny.

div.stage: Enter Hauns, and Rose arm in arm.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.l: How happy am I by embracing thee,
O I did fear such cross mishaps did reign,
That I should never see my Rose again.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Sweet Lacy, since fair opportunity
Offers herself to further our escape,
Let not too overfond esteem of me
Hinder that happy hour, invent the means,
And Rose will follow thee through all the world.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.l: O how I surfeit with excess of joy,
Made happy by thy rich perfection,
But since thou payest sweet interest to my hopes,
Redoubling love on love, let me once more,
Like to a bold faced debtor crave of thee,
This night to steal abroad, and at Eyre's house,
Who now by death of certain aldermen,
Is mayor of London, and my master once,
Meet thou thy Lacy where in spite of change,
Your father's anger, and mine uncle's hate,
Our happy nuptials will me consummate.

sp.speaker: Sib
sp.p: O God, what will you do mistress? shift for yourself, your father is at hand, he's coming, he's coming, master Lacy hide yourself in my mistress, for god's sake shift for yourselves.

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.l: Your father come, sweet Rose, what shall I do?
Where shall I hide me? how shall I escape?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: A man and want wit in extremity,
Come, come, be Hauns still, play the shoemaker,
Pull on my shoe.

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.p: Mas, and that's well remembered.

sp.speaker: Sib
sp.p: Here comes your father.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Forward metresse, 'tis un good skow, it sal vel dute, or ye sal neit betallen.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: O God it pincheth me, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Your father's presence pincheth, not the shoe.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.p: Well done, fit my daughter well, and she shall please thee well.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yaw, yaw, ick weit dat well, for ware 'tis un good shoe, 'tis gi mait van neits leither, see enter mine here.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.p: I do believe it, what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Please you, the Earl of Lincoln at the gate is newly lighted, and would speak with you.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.l: The Earl of Lincoln come speak with me?
Well, well, I know his errand: daughter Rose,
Send hence your shoemaker, dispatch, have done:
Sib, make things handsome: sir boy follow me.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.l: Mine uncle come, o what may this portend?
Sweet Rose, this of our love threatens an end.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.l: Be not dismayed at this whate'er befall,
Rose is thine own, to witness I speak truth,
Where thou appoints the place I'll meet with thee,
I will not fix a day to follow thee,
But presently steal hence, do not reply.
Love which gave strength to bear my father's hate,
Shall now add wings to further our escape.

sp.speaker: L. Mai.
sp.l: Believe me, on my credit I speak truth,
Since first your nephew Lacy went to France,
I have not seen him. It seemed strange to me,
When Dodger told me that he stayed behind,
neglecting the high charge the King imposed.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.l: Trust me (Sir Roger Otly) I did think
Your counsel had given head to this attempt,
Drawn to it by the love he bears your child.
Here I did hope to find him in your house,
But now I see mine error, and confess
My judgement wronged you by conceving so.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: Lodge in my house, say you? trust me my lord,
I love your nephew Lacy too too dear
So much to wrong his honour, and he hath done so,
That first gave him advice to stay from France.
To witness I speak truth, I let you know
How careful I have been to keep my daughter
Free from all conference, or speech of him,
Not that I scorn your nephew, but in love
I bear your honour, lest your noble blood,
Should by my mean worth be dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: How far the churl's tongue wanders from his heart,
Well, well sir Roger Otley I believe you,
With more than many thanks for the kind love,
So much you seem to bear me: but my lord,
Let me request your help to seek my nephew,
Whom if I find, I'll straight embark for France,
So shall my Rose be free, your thoughts at rest,
And much care die which now dies in my breast.

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: O lord, help for god's sake, my mistress, o my young mistress.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Where is thy mistress? what's become of her?

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: She's gone, she's fled.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Gone? whither is she fled?

sp.speaker: Sibill.
sp.p: I know not forsooth, she's fled out of doors with Hauns the shoemaker, I saw them scud, scud, scud, apace, apace.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Which way? what John, where be my men? which way?

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: I know not, and it please your worship.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Fled with a shoemaker, can this be true?

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: O lord sir, as true as gods in heaven.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Her love turned shoemaker? I am glad of this.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: A fleming butter bore, a shoemaker,
Will she forget her birth? requite my care
With such ingratitude? scorned she young Hammon,
To love a honnikin, a needy knave?
Well let her fly, I'll not fly after her,
Let her starve if she will, she's none of mine.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Be not so cruel sir.

sp.speaker: Sibil
sp.p: I am glad she's scaped.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: I'll not account of her as of my child:
Was there no better object for her eyes,
But a foul drunken lubber, swill belly,
A shoemaker, that's brave.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Yea forsooth, 'tis a very brave shoe, and as fit as a padding.

sp.speaker: L. ma
sp.p: How now, what knave is this, from whence comest thou?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: No knave sir, I am Firke the shoemaker, lusty Roger's chief lusty journeyman, and I come hither to take up the pretty leg of sweet mistress Rose, and thus hoping your worship is in as good health as I was at the making hereof, I bid you farewell, yours Firk.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Stay stay sir knave.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Come hither shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: 'Tis happy the knave is put before the shoemaker, or else I would not have vouchsafed to come back to you, I am moved, for I stir.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: My lord, this villain calls us knaves by craft.

sp.speaker: Firk.
sp.p: Then 'tis by the gentle craft, and to call one knave gently, is no harm: sit your worship merry: Sib your young mistress I'll so bob then, now my master m. Eyre is lord mayor of London.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Tell me sirrah, who's man are you?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: I am glad to see your worship so merry, I have no maw to this gear, no stomach as yet to a red petticoat.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.l: He means not sir to woo you to his maid,
But only doth demand whose man you are.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: I sing now to the tune of Rogero ▪ Roger my fellow is now my master.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Sirrah, knowest thou one Hauns a shoemaker?

sp.speaker: Firk
sp.p: Hauns shoemaker, o yes, stay, yes I have him, I tell you what, I speak it in secret, mistress Rose, and he are by this time: no not so, but shortly are to come over one another with, can you dance the shaking of the sheets? it is that Hauns, I'll so gull these diggers.

sp.speaker: L. ma
sp.p: Know'st thou then where he is?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Yes forsooth, yea marry.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Canst thou in sadness?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: No forsooth, no marry.

sp.speaker: L. ma
sp.l: Tell me good honest fellow where he is,
And thou shalt see what I'll bestow of thee.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Honest fellow, no sir, not so sir, my profession is the gentle craft, I care not for seeing, I love feeling, let me feel it here, aurium tenus, ten pieces of gold, genuum tenus, ten pieces of silver, and then Firk is your man in a new pair of strechers.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: Here is an angel, part of thy reward,
Which I will give thee, tell me where he is.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: No point: shall I betray my brother? no, shall I prove Judas to Hans? no, shall I cry treason to my corporation? no, I shall be firked and yerked then, but give me your angel, your angel shall tell you.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Do so good fellow, 'tis no hurt to thee.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Send simpering Sib away.

sp.speaker: L. ma
sp.p: Housewife, get you in.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Pitchers have ears, and maids have wide mouths: but for Hauns Prawn's, upon my word tomorrow morning, he and young mistress Rose go to this gear, they shall be married together, by this rush, or else turn Firk to a firkin of butter to tanne leather withal.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: But art thou sure of this?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Am I sure that Paul's steeple is a handful higher than London stone? or that the pissing conduit leaks nothing but pure mother bunch? am I sure I am lusty Firke, God's nails do you think I am so base to gull you?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Where are they married? dost thou know the church?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: I never go to church, but I know the name of it, it is a swearing church, stay a while, 'tis: I by the mass, no, no, 'tis I by my troth, no nor that, 'tis I by my faith, that that, 'tis I by my faith's church under Paul's cross, there they shall be knit like a pair of stockings in matrimony, there they'll be in conie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Upon my life, my nephew Lacy walks
In the disguise of this Dutch shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Doth he not honest fellow?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: No forsooth, I think Hauns is nobody , but Hans no spirit.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: My mind misgives me now 'tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My cousin speaks the language, knows the trade.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: Let me request your company my lord,
Your honourable presence may, no doubt,
Refrain their headstrong rashness, when myself
Going alone perchance may be o'erborne,
Shall I request this favour?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: This, or what else.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Then you must rise betimes, for they mean to fall to their hay pass, and repass, pindy-pandy , which hand will you have, very early.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: My care shall every way equal their haste,
This night accept your lodging in my house,
The earlier shall we stir, and at saint faithes
Prevent this giddy harebrained nuptial,
This traffic of hot love shall yield cold gains,
They ban our loves, and we'll forbid their banns.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: At saint faith's church thou sayest.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Yes, by their troth.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Be secret on thy life.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p:
Yes, when I kiss your wife, ha, ha, here's no craft in the gentle craft, I came hither of purpose with shoes to sir Roger's worship, whilst Rose his daughter be coney-catched by Hauns: soft now, these two gulls will be at saint faith's church tomorrow morning, to take master bridegroom, and mistress bride napping, and they in the mean time shall chop up the matter at the Savoy: but the best sport is, sir Roger Otly will find my fellow lame, Rafe's wife going
to marry a gentleman, and then he'll stop her in steed of his daughter; o brave, there will be fine tickling sport: soft now, what have I to do? o I know now a mess of shoemaker's meat at the wool sack in I vie lane, to cozen my gentleman of lame Rafe's wife, that's true, alack, alack girls, hold out tack, for now smocks for this tumbling shall go to wrack. Exit

div.stage: Enter air, his wife, hauns, and Rose.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: This is the morning then, stay my bully my honest Hauns, is it not?

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.p: This is the morning that must make us two happy, or miserable, therefore if you

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Away with these iffes and ands Hauns, and these et caeteraes, by mine honour Rowland Lacy none but the King shall wrong thee: come, fear nothing, am not I Sim Eyre? Is not Sim Eyre lord mayor of London? fear nothing Rose, let them all say what they can, dainty come thou to me: laughest thou?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Good my lord, stand her friend in what thing you may.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Why my sweet lady Madgy, think you Simon Eyre can forget his fine Dutch journeyman? No vah. Fie I scorn it, it shall never be cast in my teeth, that I was unthankful. Lady Madgy, thou hadst never covered thy Saracens head with this French flap, nor loaden thy bum with this farthingale, 'tis trash, trumpery, vanity, Simon Eyre had never walked in a red petticoat, nor wore a chain of gold, but for my fine journeyman's portigues, and shall I leave him? No: prince am I none, yet bear a princely mind.

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.p: My lord, 'tis time for us to part from hence.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Lady Madgy, lady Madgy, take two or thrée of my piecrust eaters, my buff-jerkin varlets, that do walk in black gowns at Simon Eyre's heels, take them good lady Madgy, trip and go, my brown Queen of periwigs, with my delicate Rose, and my jolly Rowland to the Savoy, see them linked, countenance the marriage, and when it is done, cling, cling together, you Bamborow turtle doves, I'll bear you out, come to Simon Eyre, come dwell with me Hauns, thou shalt eat minede pies, and marchpane. Rose, away cricket, trip and go, my lady Madgy to the Savoy, Hauns, wed, and to bed, kiss and away, go, vanish.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Farewell my lord.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.p: Make haste sweet love.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: She'd fain the deed were done.

sp.speaker: Hauns
sp.p: Come my sweet Rose, faster than dear we'll run.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p:
Go, vanish, vanish, avaunt I say: by the lord of Ludgate, it's a mad life to be a lord mayor, it's a stirring life, a fine life, a velvet life, a careful life. Well Simon Eyre, yet set a good face on it, in the honour of saint Hugh. Soft, the King this day comes to dine with me, to see my new buildings, his majesty is welcome, he shall have good cheer, delicate cheer, princely cheer. This day my fellow prentices of London come to dine with me too, they shall have fine cheer, gentlemanlike cheer. I promised the mad Cappidosians, when we all served at the conduit together, that if ever I came to be mayor of London, I would feast them all, and I'll do't, I'll do't by the life of Pharaoh, by this beard Sim Eire will be no flincher. Besides, I have procured, that upon
every Shrove-tuesday, at the sound of the pancake bell: my fine dapper Allyrian lads, shall clap up their shop windows, and away, this is the day, and this day they shall do't, they shall do't: boys, that day are you free, let master's care, and prentices shall pray for Simon Eyre. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Hodge, Firke, Rafe, and five or six shoemakers, all with cudgels, or such weapons.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Come Rafe, stand to it Firk: my masters, as we are the brave bloods of the shoemakers, heirs apparent to saint Hugh, and perpetual benefactors to all good fellows ▪ thou shalt have no wrong, were Hammon a King of spades, he should not delve in thy close without thy sufferance: but tell me Rafe, art thou sure 'tis thy wife?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Am I sure this is Firke? This morning when I sroked on her shoes, I looked upon her, and she upon me, and sighed, asked me if ever I knew one Rafe. Yes said I: for his sake said she (Tears standing in her eyes) and for thou art somewhat like him, spend this piece of gold: I took it: my lame leg, and my travel beyond sea made me unknown, all is one for that, I know she's mine.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Did she give thee this gold? O glorious glittering gold; she's thine own, 'tis thy wife, and she loves thee, for I'll stand to't, there's no woman will give gold to any man, but she thinks better of him than she thinks of them she gives silver to: and for Hamon, neither Hamon nor hangman shall wrong thee in London: is not òur old master Eire lord mayor? Speak my hearts.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Yes, and Hamon shall know it to his cost.

div.stage: Enter hamon, his man, Jane, and other.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Peace my bullies, yonder they come.

sp.speaker: Rafe,
sp.p: Stand to't my hearts, Firk, let me speak first.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: No Rafe, let me: Hammon, whither away so early?

sp.speaker: Hamon
sp.p: Unmannerly rude slave, what's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: To him sir? yes sir, and to me, and others: good morrow Jane, how dost thou? good lord, how the world is changed with you, God be thanked.

sp.speaker: Hamon
sp.p: Villains, hands off, how dare you touch my love?

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Villains? down with them, cry clubs for prentices.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: How, my hearts touch her Hamon? yea and more than that, we'll carry her away with us. My masters and gentlemen, never draw your bird spits, shoemakers are steel to the back, men every inch of them, all spirit.

sp.speaker: Alderman of Hamon's side
sp.p: Well, and what of all this?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: I'll show you: Jane, dost thou know this man? 'tis Rafe I can tell thee: nay, 'tis he in faith, though he be lamed by the wars, yet look not strange, but run to him, fold him about the neck and kiss him.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.l: Lives then my husband? o God let me go,
Let me embrace my Rafe.

sp.speaker: Hamon
sp.p: What means my Jane?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Nay, what meant yond to tell me he was slain?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Pardon me dear love for being misled,
'Twas rumoured here in London thou wert dead.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Thou seest he lives: lass, go pack home with him: now m. Hamon, where's your mistress your wife?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: 'Swounds m. fight for her, will you thus lose her?

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Down with that creature, clubs, down with him.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hold fool, sirs he shall do no wrong,
Will my Jane leave me thus, and break her faith?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Yea sir, she must sir, she shall sir, what then? mend it.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Hark fellow Rafe, follow my counsel, set the wench in the midst, and let her choose her man, and let her be his woman.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.l: Whom should I choose? whom should my thoughts affect?
But him whom heaven hath made to be my love,
Thou art my husband and these humble weeds,
Makes thee more beautiful than all his wealth,
Therefore I will but put off his attire,
Returning it into the owner's hand,
And after ever be thy constant wife.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Not a rag Jane, the law's on our side, he that sows in another man's ground forfeits his harvest, get thee home Rafe, follow him Jane, he shall not have so much as a busk point from thee.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Stand to that Rafe, the appurtenances are thine own, Hammon, look not at her.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: O 'swounds no.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Blue coat be quiet, we'll give you a new livery else, we'll make Shrove Tuesday saint George's day for you: look not Hammon, leer not, I'll Firk you, for thy head now, one glance, one sheep's eye, any thing at her, touch not a rag, lest I and my brothers beat you to clouts.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Come master Hammon, there's no striving here.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good fellows, hear me speak: and honest Rafe,
Whom I have injured most by loving Jane,
Mark what I offer thee: here in fair gold
Is twenty pound, I'll give it for thy Jane,
If this content thee not, thou shalt have more.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Saddle not thy wife Rafe, make her not a whore.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Say, wilt thou freely cease thy claim in her,
And let her be my wife?

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: No, do not Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p:
Sirrah Hammon Hammon, dost thou think a shoemaker is so base, to be a bawd to his own wife for commodity, take thy gold, choke with it, were
I not lame, I would make thee eat thy words.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: A shoemaker sell his flesh and blood, o indignity!

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Sirrah, take up your pelf, and be packing.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: I will not touch one penny, but in lieu
Of that great wrong I offered thy Jane,
To Jane and thee I give that twenty pound,
Since I have failed of her, during my life
I vow no woman else shall be my wife:
Farewell good fellows of the gentle trade,
Your morning's mirth my mourning day hath made.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Touch the gold creature if you dare, you're best be trudging: here Jane take thou it, now lets home my hearts.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Stay, who comes here? Jane, on again with thy mask.

div.stage: Enter Lincoln, L. Maior, and servants.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Yonder's the lying varlet mocked us so.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Come hither sirrah.

sp.speaker: Firke.
sp.p: Ay sir, I am sirrah, you mean me, do you not?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Where is my nephew married?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Is he married? God give him joy, I am glad of it: they have a fair day, and the sign is in a good planet, Mars in Venus.

sp.speaker: L. ma
sp.l: Villain, thou toldst, me that my daughter Rose,
This morning should be married at saint faithes,
We have watched there these thrée hours at the least,
Yet see we no such thing.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Truly I am sorry for't, a bride's a pretty thing.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Come to the purpose, yonder's the bride and bridegroom you look for I hope: though you be lords, you are not to bar, by your authority, men from women, are you?

sp.speaker: L. ma
sp.p: See see my daughters masked.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.l: True, and my nephew.
To hide his guilt, counterfeits him lame.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Yea truly god help the poor couple, they are lame and blind.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: I'll ease her blindness.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I'll his lameness cure.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Lie down sirs, and laugh, my fellow Rafe is taken for Rowland Lacy, and Jane for mistress damask rose, this is all my knavery.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: What, have I found you minion?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.l: O base wretch,
Nay hide thy face, the horror of thy guilt,
Can hardly be washed off: where are thy powers?
What vattels have you made? O yes I see
Thou foughtst with shame, and shame hath conquered thee.
This lameness will not serve.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Unmask yourself.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Lead home your daughter.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Take your nephew hence.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Hence, 'swounds, what mean you? are you mad? I hope you cannot enforce my wife from me, where's Hamon?

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: What Hammon?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Yea my wife, and therefore the proudest of you that lays hands on her first, I'll lay my crutch cross his pate.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: To him lame Rafe, here's brave sport.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Rose call you her? why her name is Jane, look here else, do you know her now?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Is this your daughter?

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.l: No, nor this your nephew:
My lord of Lincoln, we are both abused
By this base crafty varlet.

sp.speaker: Firk
sp.p: Yea forsooth no varlet, forsooth no base, forsooth I am but mean, no crattie neither, but of the gentle craft.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Where is my daughter Rose? where is my child?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Where is my nephew Lacy married?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Why here is good laid mutton as I promised you.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Villain, I'll have thee punished for this wrong.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Punish the journeyman villain, but not the journeyman shoemaker. Enter Dodger.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.l: My lord I come to bring unwelcome news,
Your nephew Lacy, and your daughter Rose,
Early this morning wedded at the Savoy,
None being present but the lady Mairesse:
Besides I learned among the officers,
The lord maior vows to stand in their defence,
'Gainst any that shall seek to cross the match.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Dares Eyre the shoemaker uphold the deed?

sp.speaker: Firk
sp.p: Yes sir, shoemakers dare stand in a woman's quarrel I warrant you, as deep as another, and deeper too.

sp.speaker: Dod.
sp.l: Besides, his grace, today dines with the mayor,
Who on his knees humbly intends to fall,
And beg a pardon for your nephew's fault.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: But I'll prevent him come sir Roger Oteley,
The King will do us justice in this cause,
Howe'er their hands have made them man and wife,
I will disjoin the match, or lose my life.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Adieu monsieur Dodger, farewell fools, ha ha, o if they had stayed I would have so lambed them with flouts, oh heart, my codpiece point is ready to fly in pieces every time I think upon mistress Rose, but let that pass, as my lady Mairesse says.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: This matter is answered: come Rafe, home with thy wife, come my fine shoemakers, let's to our masters the new lord maior and there swagger this Shrove Tuesday, I'll promise you wine enough, for Madge keeps the seller.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: O rare! Madge is a good wench.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p:
And I'll promise you meat enough, for simpering
Susan keeps the larder, I'll lead you to victuals my brave soldiers, follow your captain, oh brave, hark, hark.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: The pancake bell rings, the pancake bell, tri-lill my hearts.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: O brave, o sweet bell, oh delicate pancakes, open the doors my hearts, and shut up the windows, keep in the house, let out the pancakes: o rare my hearts, let's march together for the honour of saint Hugh to the great new hall in gracious street corner, which our master the new lord maior hath built.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: O the crew of good fellows that will dine at my lord, mayor's cost today!

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: By the lord, my lord maior is a most brave man, how shall prentices be bound to pray for him, and the honour of the gentlemen shoemakers? let's feed and be fat with my lord's bounty.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.p: O musical be still! O Hodge, oh my brothers! there's cheer for the heavens, venison pastimes walk up and down piping hot, like sergeants, beef and brewis comes marching in dry fats, fritters and pancakes comes trolling in in wheel barrows, hens and oranges hopping in porters baskets, collops and eggs in scuttles, and tarts and custards comes quavering in in malt shovels.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Whoop, look here, look here.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: How now mad lads, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: I. Pren.
sp.p: Whither, why to the great new hall, know you not why? The lord maior hath bidden all the prentices in London to breakfast this morning.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: O brave shoemaker, o brave lord of incomprehensible good fellowship, who, hark you, the pancake bell rings. Cast up caps.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Nay more my hearts, every Shrove-tuesday is our year of jubilee: and when the pancake bell rings, we are as free as my lord mayor, we may shut up our shops, and make holiday: I'll have it called, saint Hugh's holiday.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Agreed, agreed, saint Hugh's holiday.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: And this shall continue for ever.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: O brave! come come my hearts, away, away.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: O eternal credit to us of the gentle craft, march fair my hearts, o rare.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King and his train over the stage.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Is our lord mayor of London such a gallant?

sp.speaker: Noble man
sp.l: One of the merriest madcaps in your land,
Your grace will think, when you behold the man,
He's rather a wild ruffian than a mayor:
Yet thus much I'll ensure your majesty,
In all his actions that concern his state,
He is as serious, provident, and wise,
As full of gravity amongst the grave,
As any mayor hath been these many years.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am with child till I behold this half cap,
But all my doubt is, when we come in presence,
His madness will be dashed clean out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Noble man
sp.p: It may be so, my liege.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Which to prevent,
Let some one give him notice, 'tis our pleasure,
That he put on his wonted merriment:
Set forward.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: On afore.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter air Hodge, Firke, Rafe, and other shoemakers, all with napkins on their shoulders.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p:
Come my fine Hodge, my jolly gentlemen shoemakers, soft, where be these cannibals, these varlets my officers, let them all walk and wait upon my brothers, for my meaning is, that none but shoemakers, none but the livery
of my company shall in their satin hoods wait upon the trencher of my sovereign.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: O my lord, it will be rare.

sp.speaker: Ayre
sp.p: No more Firk, come lively, let your fellow prentices want no cheer, let wine be plentiful as beer, and beer as water, hang these penny pinching fathers, that cram wealth in innocent lamb skins, rip knaves, avaunt, look to my guests

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: My lord, we are at our wits end for room, those hundred tables will not feast the fourth part of them.

sp.speaker: Ayre
sp.p: Then cover me those hundred tables again, and again, till all my jolly prentices be feasted: avoid Hodge, run Rafe, frisk about my numble Firke, carouse me fathom healths to the honour of the shoemakers: do they drink lively Hodge? do they tickle it Firk?

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Tickle it? some of them have taken their liquour standing so long, that they can stand no longer: but for meat, they would eat it and they had it.

sp.speaker: Ayre
sp.p: Want they meat? where's this swagbelly, this greasy kitchenstuff cook, call the varlet to me: want meat! Firk, Hodge, lame Rafe, run my tall men, beleaguer the shambles, beggar all Eastcheap, serve me whole oxen in chargers, and let sheep whine upon the tables like pigs for want of good fellows to eat them. Want meat! vanish Firk, avaunt Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.p: Your lordship mistakes my man Firk, he means their bellies want meat, not the boards, for they have drunk so much they can eat nothing.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Where is my lord.

sp.speaker: Ayre
sp.p: How now lady Madgy.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p:
The Kings most excellent majesty is new come, he sends me for thy honour: one of his most worshipful peers,
bade me tell thou must be merry, and so forth: but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Is my sovereign come? vanish my tall shoemakers, my nimble brothers, look to my guests the prentices: yet stay a little, how now Hans, how looks my little Rose?

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.l: Let me request you to remember me,
I know your honour easily may obtain,
Free pardon of the King for me and Rose,
And reconcile me to my uncle's grace.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Have done my good Hans, my honest journeyman, look cheerly, I'll fall upon both my knees till they be as hard as horn, but I'll get thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Good my lord have a care what you speak to his grace.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Away you I slington whitepot, hence you happerarse, you barley pudding full of maggots, you broiled carbonado, avaunt, avaunt, avoid Mephistopheles: shall Sim Eyre leave to speak of you lady Madgy? vanish mother Miniver cap, vanish, go, trip and go, meddle with your partlets, and your pishery-pashery , your flewes and your whirligigs, go, rub, out of mine alley: Sim Eyre knows how to speak to a Pope, to sultan Soliman, to Tamburlaine and he were here: and shall I melt? shall I droop before my sovereign? no, come my lady Madgy, follow me Hauns, about your business my frolic freebooters: Firk, frisk about, and about, and about, for the honour of mad Simon Eyre lord mayor of London.

sp.speaker: Firke
sp.p: Hey for the honour of the shoemakers.Exeunt.
sp.stage: A long flourish or two: enter King, nobles, Eyre, his wife, Lacy, Rose: Lacy and Rose kneel.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Well Lacy though the fact was very foul,
Of your revolting from our kingly love,
And your own duty, yet we pardon you,
Rise both, and mistress Lacy, thank my lord mayor
for your young bridegroom here.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: So my dear liege, Sim Eyre and my brothers the gentlemen shoemakers shall set your sweet majesty's image, cheek by jowl by saint Hugh, for this honour you have done poor Simon Eyre, I beseeth your grace pardon my rude behaviour, I am a handicrafts man, yet my heart is without craft, I would be sorry at my soul, that my boldness should offend my King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Nay, I pray thee good lord maior, be even as merry as if thou wert among thy shoemakers, it does me good to see thee in this humour.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Sayest thou me so my sweet Dioclesian? then hump, prince am I none, yet am I princely born, by the lord of Ludgate my liege, I'll be as merry as a pie.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Tell me in faith mad Eyre, how old thou art.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: My liege a very boy, a stripling, a younker, you see not a white hair on my head, not a grey in this beard, every hair I assure thy majesty that sticks in this beard, Sim Eyre values at the King of Babylon's ransom, Tama cham's beard was a rubbing brush to't: yet I'll shave it off, and stuff tennis balls with it to please my bully King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: But all this while I do not know your age.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p:
My liege, I am six and fifty year old, yet I can cry humpe, with a sound heart for the honour of saint Hugh: mark this old wench, my King, I danced the shaking of the sheets with her six and thirty years ago, and yet I hope to get two or three young lord majors ere I die: I am lusty still, Sim Eyre still: care, and cold lodging brings white hairs. My sweet majesty, let care vanish, cast it upon thy nobles, it will make thee look always young like Apollo, and cry humpe: prince am I none, yet am
I princely born.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Ha ha: say Cornwall, didst thou ever see his like?

sp.speaker: Noble man
sp.p: Not I, my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Lincoln, what news with you?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.l: My gracious lord, have care unto yourself,
For there are traitors here.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Traitors, where? who?

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Traitors in my house? God forbid, where be my officers? I'll spend my soul ere my King feel harm.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Where is the traitor? Lincoln.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Here he stands.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Cornwall, lay hold on Lacy: Lincoln, speak:
What canst thou lay unto thy nephew's charge?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.l: This my dear liege: your grace to do me honour,
Heaped on the head of this degenerous boy,
Desertless favours, you made choice of him,
To be commander over powers in France,
But he.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Good Lincoln pry thee pause a while,
Even in thine eyes I read what thou wouldst speak,
I know how Lacy did neglect our love,
Ran himself deeply (In the highest degree)
Into vile treason.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: Is he not a traitor?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Lincoln, he was: now have we pardoned him,
'Twas not a base want of true valour's fire,
That held him out of France, but love's desire.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: I will not bear his shame upon my back.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Nor shalt thou Lincoln, I forgive you both.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.l: Then (Good my liege) forbid the boy to wed
One, whose mean birth will much disgrace his bed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Are they not married?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: No my liege.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shall I divorce them then? O be it far,
That any hand on earth should dare untie,
The sacred knot knit by God's majesty,
I would not for my crown disjoin their hands,
That are conjoined in holy nuptial bands,
How sayest thou Lacy? wouldst thou lose thy Rose?

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.p: Not for all Indians wealth, my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: But Rose I am sure her Lacy would forgo.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.p: If Rose were asked that question, she say, no.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: You hear them Lincoln.

sp.speaker: Linc
sp.p: Yea my liege, I do.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Yet canst thou find ith' heart to part these two?
Who seeks, besides you, to divorce these lovers?

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: I do (My gracious lord) I am her father.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Sir Roger Oteley, our last mayor I think,

sp.speaker: Nob
sp.p: The same my liege.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Would you offend love's laws?
Well, you shall have your wills, you sue to me,
To prohibit the match: soft, let me see,
You both are married, Lacy, art thou not?

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.p: I am, dread sovereign.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then upon thy life,
I charge thee, not to call this woman wife.

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.p: O my most gracious lord!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nay Rose, never woo me, I tell you true,
Although as yet I am a bachelor,
Yet I believe I shall not marry you.

sp.speaker: Rose
sp.l: Can you divide the body from the soul,
Yet make the body live?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Yea, so profound?
I cannot Rose, but you I must divide:
Fair maid, this bridegroom cannot be your bride.
Are you pleased Lincoln? Oteley, are you pleased?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then must my heart be eased,
For credit me, my conscience lives in pain,
Till these whom I divorced be joined again:
Lacy, give me thy hand, Rose, lend me thine.
Be what you would be: kiss now: so, that's fine,
At night (Lovers) to bed: now let me see,
Which of you all mislikes this harmony?

sp.speaker: L. mayor
sp.p: Will you then take from me my child perforce?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why tell me Oteley, shines not Lacy's name,
As bright in the world's eye, as the gay beams
Of any citizen?

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.l: Yea but my gracious lord,
I do mislike the match far more than he,
Her blood is too too base.

sp.speaker: King Lincoln,
sp.l: No more,
Dost thou not know, that love respects no blood?
Cares not for difference of birth, or state,
The maid is young, well born, fair, virtuous,
A worthy bride for any gentleman:
Besides, your nephew for her sake did stoop
To bare necessity: and as I hear,
Forgetting honours, and all courtly pleasures,
To gain her love, became a shoemaker.
As for the honour which he lost in France,
Thus I redeem it: Lacy, kneel thee down,
Arise sir Rowland Lacy: tell me now,
tell me in earnest Oteley, canst thou chide?
Seeing thy Rose a lady and a bride.

sp.speaker: Lord mayor.
sp.p: I am content with what your grace hath done.

sp.speaker: Linc.
sp.p: And I my liege, since there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come on then, at shake hands, I'll have you friends,
Where there is much love, all discord ends,
What says my mad lord mayor to all this love?

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: O my liege, this honour you have done to my fine journeyman here, Rowland Lacy, and all these favours which you have shown to me this day in my poor house, will make Simon Eyre live longer by one dozen of warm summers more than he should.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nay, my mad lord maior (That shall be thy name)
If any grace of mine can length thy life,
One honour more I'll do thee, that new building,
Which at thy cost in Cornhill is erected,
Shall take a name from us, we'll have it called,
The leaden hall, because in digging it,
You found the lead that covereth the same.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: I thank your majesty.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: God bless your grace.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Lincoln, a word with you.

div.stage: Enter Hodge, Firke, Rafe, and more shoemakers.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: How now my mad knaves? Peace, speak softly, yonder is the King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: With the old troop which there we keep in pay,
We will incorporate a new supply:
Before one summer more pass o'er my head,
France shall repent England was injured.
What are all those?

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.l: All shoemakers, my liege,
sometimes my fellows, in their companies
I lived as merry as an emperor.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: My mad lord mayor, are all these shoemakers?

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: All shoemakers, my liege, all gentlemen of the gentle craft, true Trojans, courageous cordwainers, they all kneel to the shrine of holy saint Hugh.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: God save your majesty all shoemakers

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Mad Simon, would they any thing with us?

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Mum mad knaves, not a word, I'll do't, I warrant you. They are all beggars, my liege, all for themselves: and I for them all, on both my knees do entreat, that for the honour of poor Simon Eyre, and the good of his brothers these mad knaves, your grace would vouchsafe some privilege to my new Leden hall, that it may be lawful for us to buy and sell leather there two days a week.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mad Sim, I grant your suit, you shall have patent
To hold two market days in Leden hall,
Mondayes and Fridayes, those shall be the times:
Will this content you?

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Jesus bless your grace.

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: In the name of these my poor brothers shoemakers, I most humbly thank your grace. But before I rise, seeing you are in the giving vain, and we in the begging, grant Sim Eyre one boon more.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: What is it my lord maior?

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: Vouchsafe to taste of a poor banquet that stands sweetly waiting for your sweet presence.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I shall undo thee Eyre, only with feasts,
Already have I been too troublesome,
Say, have I not?

sp.speaker: Eyre
sp.p: O my dear King, Sim Eyre was taken unawares upon a day of shroving which I promised long ago to the prentices of London: for an't please your highness, in time passed
sp.l: I bore the water tanker 〈◊〉 my coat
Sits not a whit the world 〈◊〉 my back:
And then upon a morning some mad boys,
It was Shrove-tuesday even as 'tis now,
sp.p: Gave me my breakfast, and I swore then by the stopple of my tankard, if ever I came to be lord mayor of London, I would feast all the prentices, this day (My liege) I did it, and the slaves had an hundred tables five times covered, they are gone home and vanished: yet add more honour to the gentle trade, taste of Eyre's banquet, simon's happy made.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Eyre, I will taste of thy banquet, and will say,
I have not met more pleasure on a day,
Friends of the gentle craft, thanks to you all,
Thanks my kind lady Mairesse for our there,
Come lords, a white let's revel it at home,
When all our sports, and banquetings are dome,
War's most right wrongs which Frenchmen have begun.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
